question: Q. What is a sacrament?
answer: A. A sacrament is a holy ordinance instituted by Christ, wherein, by sensible signs, Christ and the benefits of the new covenant are represented, sealed, and applied to believers. (WSC 92) (Gal. 3:27; 1 Cor. 10:16).

question: Q. How are sacraments a sign?
answer: A. A sign is the physical element (water, bread, wine) that points to the spiritual reality (union with Christ, forgiveness of sins).

question: Q. How are sacraments a seal?
answer: A. A seal is a confirmation or guarantee that the spiritual reality is truly present and being conveyed to the believer.

question: Q.What does “sacramental union” mean?
answer: A. The relationship between the sign and the thing signified — when we call the bread the body of Christ.

question: Q. Who may administer the sacraments?
answer: A. A lawfully ordained minister. Sacraments are tied to the ministry of the Word (Matt. 28), and ministers are called and ordained to serve as Christ’s representatives (1 Cor. 4; Titus 1).

question: Q. What sacraments of the Old Testament are tied to the sacraments of the New Testament?
answer:
A. Circumcision to Baptism: Circumcision, the sign of the covenant with Abraham (Genesis 17:10-11), marked inclusion in God’s covenant community. In the New Testament, baptism replaces circumcision as the sign of the covenant (Colossians 2:11-12).

Passover to the Lord’s Supper: The Passover commemorated Israel's deliverance from Egypt through the blood of the lamb (Exodus 12:21-27). The Lord’s Supper, instituted by Christ during Passover (Luke 22:19-20), fulfills this by pointing to Jesus, the Lamb of God (1 Corinthians 5:7), whose sacrifice delivers believers from sin.

question: Q. What is baptism?
answer: A. Baptism is a sacrament, wherein the washing with water, in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost (Matt. 28), does signify and seal our ingrafting into Christ (Gal. 3); and partaking of the benefits of the covenant of grace (Acts 2); and our engagement to be the Lord's (Rom. 6).

question: Q. What is the language of sign and seal in baptism?
answer: A. Baptism is an outward sign of one’s allegiance to and ownership by Jesus Christ. We are baptized into the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. Hence, baptism serves as a public sign indicating one’s desire to be identified with God. Baptism is the visible ratification on the part of God that He indeed does forgive the sins of those who believe in the Lord Jesus Christ. (Rom. 4:11; Gen. 9:12-13; 17:11). The term 'seal' means that baptism is a guarantee and confirmation of the grace which it signifies (Rom. 2; 4; Ex. 12). This relates to paedo-baptism because when an infant is baptized, God is marking that child as His, and providing confirmation of His promise to bestow on that child the blessings of the covenant of grace.

question: Q. Give a BRIEF explanation and defense of infant baptism.
answer: A. As the covenant sign of the OT was applied to infant males in circumcision, we baptize infants because they are included in the covenantal promise which is "for you and your children", and the children of believers are to be received into the covenant community and given the connected sign and seal (Acts 2, 16).

question: Q. Who is to be baptized?
answer: A. Those who profess faith and obedience in Jesus Christ and the infant children of believing parents (one, or both) – WCF 27.4. For profession of faith baptism, see Acts 2 (Peter on Pentecost), Mark 16:15-16 (Jesus and His Great Commission), Acts 8 (Ethiopian Eunuch). For infant baptism see Gen. 17, Acts 2, 1 Cor. 7 (unbelieving spouse and children are sanctified by the believing spouse), Mark 10 and Luke 18 – where Jesus blesses the little children.

question: Q. What is the Lord's Supper?
answer: A. The Lord’s Supper is a sacrament wherein, by giving and receiving of bread and wine, according to Christ’s appointment, his death is showed forth; and worthy receives are, not after a corporal and carnal manner, but by faith made partakers of his body and blood, to their spiritual nourishment, and growth in grace.

question: Q. What is communion 'under both kinds'?
answer: A. Communion 'under both kinds' refers to the practice of administering the Eucharist in both forms—both the consecrated bread (the body of Christ) and the consecrated wine (the blood of Christ) to the laity.

question: Q. What is your view on the presence of Christ in the Lord’s Supper
answer: A. Through the Holy Spirit believers are lifted up to partake of Christ’s body and blood in a real, though mystical, way, receiving the benefits of His sacrifice by faith. Christ is not present physically or locally in the elements.

question: Q. How is 'fencing the table' practiced during communion?
answer: A. By reading the words of institution from either a gospel account or 1 Cor. 11, all are made aware this is an ordinance instituted by Christ. It is observed in remembrance of Christ and his death is showed forth until he comes again, and God works through this meal as a means of grace. Those who are communicants in good standing in any evangelical church or been approved by the session are invited to participate while others are invited to remain and observe.

question: Q. At what point should a covenant child be admitted to the Lord’s Supper? What is your understanding of what constitutes a ‘credible profession of faith’?
answer: A. When they confess faith and the session receives them. When they are able to assent to the membership vows.
